item.title: Where to Find Moonrithyll's Knight Sword in Elden Ring Shadow of the Erdtree
item.description:
Quick Links

  • Moonrithyll's Knight Sword Overview: Stat Requirements, Effects, & Skill
  • Where To Find Moonrithyll's Knight Sword Location

Elden Ring: Shadow of the Erdtree DLC brings with it a host of new weapons, armor, talismans, and ashes of war to discover, opening the floodgates to build experimentation and theory-crafting.

One of these is Moonrithyll's Knight Sword, a new Colossal Sword that has the exact same design as the Troll Knight's Sword but plays differently because of its unique Ash of War. Here is everything players need to know about it.

Moonrithyll's Knight Sword Overview: Stat Requirements, Effects, & Skill

Greatsword embedded with a blue glintstone. The favored weapon of the steadfast Carian knight, Moonrithyll. Moonrithyll was the Twin Moon Knight's chamberlain. She was also a friend to the trolls, who served the royal family, and proudly wielded their weapons as she fought arm in arm with her gargantuan comrades.

In Elden Ring: Shadow of the Erdtree , Moonrithyll's Knight Sword is a new weapon of the Colossal Sword weapon type . Scaling with Strength, Dexterity, and Intelligence puts the Moonrithyll Knight Sword in a difficult position. Intelligence-focused builds would much rather use the Moonlight Greatsword and mixed STR/INT or DEX/INT builds have better options.

The Moonrithyll's Knight Sword can be upgraded using Somber Smithing Stones to +10 , and cannot benefit from spell-based or consumable weapon buffs.

Moonrithyll's Knight Sword Stat Requirements

STR

DEX

INT

FAITH

ARC

20

14

18

0

0

Moonrithyll's Knight Sword Damage & Scaling

Scaling (Base)

Scaling (+10)

STR

D

STR

C

DEX

D

DEX

C

INT

D

INT

C

Moonrithyll's Knight Sword Weapon Skill: Tremendous Phalanx

The Moonrithyll's Knight Sword Ash of War is Tremendous Phalanx , which cannot be changed. It functions essentially the same as the Glintblade Phalanx , dealing magic as well as poise damage to anyone it manages to target. The casting animation is relatively short, making it possible to easily cast this mid-fight.

This weapon skill costs 16 FP to cast, and cannot be chained into a follow-up attack.

Skill of the enchanted troll knights. Creates a defensive arch of enormous magic glintblades overhead, which automatically attack nearby foes. Follow up with a strong attack to chain this skill into a lunging thrust.

Where To Find Moonrithyll's Knight Sword Location

In Elden Ring: Shadow of the Erdtree , Moonrithyll's Knight Sword is a drop for defeating Moonrithyll, Carian Knight in Castle Ensis. From the Castle Ensis Checkpoint Site of Grace, kill the soldier holding the torch facing the drop next to the blocked castle gate. Drop down to the three dogs below and kill them as well. Go through the tunnel until you reach the waterfall. Hug the left cliffside and jump across the platforms to reach the water. Take the ladder on the left side to reach a room with two soldiers. Defeat the soldiers and activate the pulley system in the room across from this one to unlock the shortcut back to the Site of Grace.

Cross the bridge and turn right, defeating all enemies along the way. Pay special attention to the dog hiding on the left side, as he chases you forever unless you kill him. Ignore the Carian Sorcerers and take the stairs to the next part of the castle, where you'll find the Moonrithyll Knight guarding the entryway.

item.title: ASKA: How to Heal and Build a Shelter
item.description:
Quick Links

  • Constructing a Shelter in ASKA
  • Steps to Build Your Shelter

With those wisps and wights relentlessly hounding you, getting around is tough. ASKA is unlike other survival games; simply eating and drinking food will not automatically heal your wounds. Hence, the quest to survive is relatively difficult here. There’s an easy fix for this though: build a shelter and rest within it.

However, to construct a shelter in ASKA , you need multiple resources and materials to succeed in this venture. These can be found in the vicinity. The following guide walks you through everything you need to know to build a shelter and care for yourself in the harsh land that awaits you in ASKA .

Constructing a Shelter in ASKA

One of the first healing steps in ASKA is to build a shelter that provides basic housing and gives you a place to regenerate your health. After creating a campfire to start the game, you should begin collecting resources needed for building your shelter. Let’s discuss the materials and tools that are needed in detail.

Essential Materials for Building a Shelter:

To construct a shelter in ASKA , you will require the following materials:

3x Long Stick

The main structural component is obtained by chopping trees with an axe. Long sticks are too big for your inventory and must be carried manually. Mark the tree location on your map.

2x Rope

This is made from two pieces of fiber gathered from plants. It is used to bind the shelter structure.

8x Stick

Additional structural support. Found on the ground or by chopping long sticks into smaller pieces.

8x Bark

Obtained by chopping down trees with an axe. Used for covering and weatherproofing.

Tools Required for Building a Shelter

In addition to gathering materials, you will need specific tools to build your shelter:

Tool

Role

Ingredients Required

Stone Axe

Essential for chopping down trees to obtain long sticks and bark.

  • 1x Stone Blade
  • 1x Stick.
  • 1x Rope.

Wooden Hammer

Used for the actual construction of the shelter.

2x Stick.

Wooden Hoe

Required to level the building land.

  • 2x Stone Blade.
  • 4x Stick.

Steps to Build Your Shelter

Once you've gathered all the necessary materials and tools, follow these steps to build your shelter:

  1. Choose a Suitable Location : Find a flat, safe, accessible area. If necessary, use the wooden hoe to level the ground.
  2. Gather and Transport Materials : Collect long sticks, ropes, sticks, and bark. Mark the resource locations on your map for easy retrieval.
  3. Construct the Shelter : Use the wooden hammer to build your shelter. Follow on-screen prompts to place materials correctly and complete the construction.
  4. Rest and Heal : Once built, rest inside the shelter to regenerate your health and recover from injuries inflicted by wisps and wights.

item.title: Super Monkey Ball Banana Rumble: How Long to Beat?
item.description:
Given the huge variety of games that are on offer these days and the sizable backlogs that many gamers have built up, deciding whether or not to spend money on a brand-new release can be a big decision for some. There are a few different factors that can help make the decision easier: one of which is completion time.

Super Monkey Ball Banana Rumble is a relatively short game when it comes to main story completion time, but there's plenty on offer for those looking to 100% complete it. The game also boasts excellent multiplayer support, so those interested in finding out how long it takes to beat Super Monkey Ball Banana Rumble should take these things into account.

How Long Does it Take to Beat Super Monkey Ball Banana Rumble?

It will take most players around four or five hours to complete Super Monkey Ball Banana Rumble 's main story, although this time can vary quite a bit depending on one's playstyle. For example, those who endeavor to 100% every stage before moving on can expect to spend significantly longer, while skilled players will likely find that they can get through the game much faster. In theory, there's less than 100 minutes of actual gameplay on offer as part of the main story, as each stage has a sixty-second time limit, and many can be completed in ten seconds or less. However, most players will likely have to replay some of the stages multiple times, and there are also cutscenes bookending each of Super Monkey Ball Banana Rumble 's ten worlds.

It's also worth noting that players can unlock 100 additional courses after completing the main story of Adventure Mode , with each world having an EX variant. These new stages are a lot harder than the first hundred, so players can expect to spend another four or five hours tackling those as well. Completing all three stage missions for every course will take longer still, meaning completionists can expect to get at least twelve hours out of the game; longer still if they are new to the franchise or if they haven't played a Super Monkey Ball game for a while.

How Does Super Monkey Ball Banana Rumble Compare to Previous Super Monkey Ball Games?

The average main story completion time for a Super Monkey Ball game is around five hours, so franchise fans will likely be pretty satisfied with what Super Monkey Ball Banana Rumble has to offer. The EX courses should be able to keep them busy long after the credits have finished rolling, while the game's fantastic multiplayer functionality means that there's still plenty of fun to be had even after all of the single-player stages have been completed.

item.title: Elden Ring: Shadow of the Erdtree - How to Get to Shadow Keep Back Gate
item.description:
Players who want to explore the area at the northeast corner of Elden Ring: Shadow of the Erdtree 's map must first reach the Shadow Keep, Back Gate Site of Grace. This journey can be quite confusing, and fans may get lost several times as they attempt to find the Site of Grace. For those fans who indeed are struggling to reach the Shadow Keep Back Gate in Elden Ring 's Shadow of the Erdtree DLC, this guide is here to help.

It is highly recommended that players collect the Scadu Altus Map Fragment in Elden Ring before they attempt to reach the Shadow Keep, Back Gate Site of Grace.

Elden Ring: Shadow of the Erdtree - How to Get to Shadow Keep Back Gate

Go to Shadow Keep, Church District

Players who are trying to reach the Shadow Keep, Back Gate should begin at the Moorth Ruins Site of Grace in Scadu Altus. From this position, fans should travel southeast to locate a ruined building with a tall turret. There is a chasm on the northeast side of that building, and players should descend to the bottom, pass through the tunnel to reach a ladder, and climb up to Elden Ring 's Bonny Village.

Players should now ride eastward to the Bridge Leading to the Village Site of Grace, and then follow the road to the north. This road will lead fans to the Church District Highroad Site of Grace, and they should continue riding to the northwest from that location to enter the Church District in Elden Ring 's Shadow Keep.

Players will encounter one of Elden Ring 's Furnace Golems during this part of the journey, but they can simply ride past it.

Go to Storehouse, Back Section

After activating the Church District Entrance Site of Grace, players should jump to the roof in front of them and navigate to its far side. Fans should then stand atop one of the roof's protrusions, jump to the wall that is ahead, and travel to its far side. Here, players will find a ramp made from rubble, and they should use it to access a ledge.

Upon reaching the ledge, Elden Ring players should turn to their left and jump to the roof that is in front of them. Fans should then turn left once again, make their way to the far side of the roof, and jump to the buttress on the left. This support can be used to access a roof that has a hole in it, and fans should fall through that hole, making sure to land on the stone arch.

Players should now cross the arch to reach a platform with a hole, and they should fall through that hole and enter the corridor that is ahead of them. As fans travel through the corridor, they will see that there are a series of doors on their left, and passing through the third door will put them on a path that leads to a lift that should be ridden. When the lift comes to a stop, players should go left to reach the Storehouse, Back Section Site of Grace in Elden Ring .

Go to Storehouse Loft

With the Storehouse, Back Section Site of Grace activated, players should climb the small flight of stairs to the west and use the ladder on the right. At the top of the ladder, players should go right, climb two flights of stairs, and pass between the two bookcases that are on the right. Fans should now see a hole in the wall to their left, and they should jump through it to access a path that leads directly to the Storehouse Loft Site of Grace.

Go to Shadow Keep, Back Gate

From the Storehouse Loft Site of Grace, players should enter the nearby lift to access the rafters. When the lift comes to a stop, Elden Ring fans should go left, left, right, right to reach a ladder that they should climb. Fans should then go forward, right, right to reach a ladder that they should descend.

Players must sprint and jump to make the final right turn in this sequence.

Players should now use the path to the left of the ladder to get above a platform with several tables and an exit. Fans should jump to that platform, pass through the exit, and ride the lift to the right. This will put players on a path that leads directly to another lift, and it can be ridden to reach the Shadow Keep, Back Gate Site of Grace.

item.title: The 30 Best-Designed Pokemon Of All Time
item.description:
If there's one thing that anyone, even people who are not fans of the franchise, can say about Pokemon is that it is a series full of wildly imaginative and unique monster designs. They are the kind of fictional creatures that spur people's imaginations. They also make it easy for the fans to become attached to the shows, trading cards, and, especially, the games and shows. Everyone has their favorite Pokemon, and they can't get enough to them.

But personal tastes aside, there are some Pokemon that go beyond the realm of being endearing. The creativity and at times beauty in the designs of some Pokemon are things that anyone should be able to admit are worth appreciating.

Updated on June 25, 2024, by Blaise Santi : It's been a few years since the release of Pokemon Scarlet & Violet, although fans of the series have been fed with the DLC expansions The Teal Mask and The Indigo Disk. However, some have their sights set on the next generation of Pokemon, which will certainly come at some point after the release of Pokemon Legends: Z-A, the follow-up to Pokemon Legends: Arceus set in the Kalos region. Before fans get to see what new Pokemon they'll eventually be able to add to their teams, let's take a look at the best-designed Pokemon the franchise has seen, with these 30 including some of the most iconic Pokemon from each of the nine generations so far.

30 Charizard

The Pokemon's Flame Will Never Burn Out

Type

Fire/Flying, Fire/Dragon (Mega Charizard X)

Abilities

Blaze, Solar Power, Tough Claws (Mega Charizard X), Drought (Mega Charizard Y)

Learned Moves

Flamethrower, Fire Fang, Air Slash, Dragon Claw, Smokescreen

Forms

Mega Charizard X, Mega Charizard Y, Gigantamax Charizard

For many fans, Charizard is their first introduction to the Pokemon franchise. It is the sixth Pokemon in the Pokedex and the mascot Pokemon for the first generation's Pokemon Red . Charizard is beyond popular in mainstream media, from Ash's disrespectful partner in the anime to its ultra-rare holo card from the original trading card game series.

Charizard remains one of the most beloved and classic dragon designs in the series, so much so that it was given two Mega Evolutions, one of which being Fire/Dragon-type. Its bright orange scales, fire-coated tail, and fearsome facial expression are why this amazing Fire/Flying-type has set the standard for other Pokemon like it.

29 Blastoise

As If Squirtle Wasn't Cool Enough

Type

Water

Abilities

Torrent, Rain Dish, Mega Launcher (Mega Blastoise)

Learned Moves

Hydro Pump, Wave Crash, Bite, Flash Cannon, Shell Smash

Forms

Mega Blastoise, Gigantamax Blastoise

Although Charizard might be the most popular Gen 1 starter evolution, Blastoise still maintains a special place in many fans’ hearts. Aside from being one of the strongest Water-type starters, Blastoise is also one of the most iconic Pokemon designs, as a hulking tortoise with cannons protruding from its shell.

Blastoise’s popularity allows it to benefit from multiple forms and designs. Both Mega Blastoise and Gigantamax Blastoise take the best aspects of the original’s look and build off of it. Despite having been around for over two decades, Blastoise is still relevant to the franchise, and its eye-grabbing design is a big reason why.

28 Pikachu

The Series Mascot Earned Its Place

Type

Electric

Abilities

Static, Lightning Rod

Learned Moves

Thunderbolt, Electro Ball, Iron Tail, Agility, Charm, Nasty Plot, Quick Attack

Forms

Cap Pikachu, Gigantamax Pikachu

Easily the most recognizable Pokemon in the world , Pikachu is an Electric-type Pokemon that routinely appears in every Pokemon game, albeit finding it in the wild can be quite difficult. It first appeared in Pokemon Red and Blue , where it can be caught in a number of locations, one example being the Viridian Forest.

Pikachu is the quintessential "cute" Pokemon and has been so for the entire span of the franchise's history. Its small dimensions and mousey features, including its adorable ears, eyes, and almost constant smile, have made owning a Pikachu in real life the impossible dream for millions of people. It's unfortunate its evolution, Raichu, doesn't get the same love.

27 Gengar

It's Haunted Many Pokemon Fans' Dreams

Type

Ghost/Poison

Abilities

Cursed Body, Shadow Tag (Mega Gengar)

Learned Moves

Shadow Ball, Night Shade, Sucker Punch, Dream Eater, Mean Look

Forms

Mega Gengar, Gigantamax Gengar

Sometimes, the most simplistic of designs are the most impactful. This is exceptionally true with Gastly's evolutionary line, ending with Gengar. As the first Ghost-type Pokemon introduced back in Generation 1, Gengar's design has withstood the test of time. It helps that its pre-evolution, Haunter, is just as iconic with its menacing face and creepy hands.

Gengarhas become an icon in its own right, appearing in a lot of Pokemon merchandise and media over the years. It's even been given alternate forms through Mega Evolution and Gigantamaxing which have only made its design age better.

26 Lapras

It's A Shame You Can't Ride One In Real Life

Type

Water/Ice

Abilities

Water Absorb, Shell Armor, Hydration

Learned Moves

Water Pulse, Brine, Ice Beam, Sheer Cold, Confuse Ray, Perish Song

Forms

Gigantamax Lapras

One of Gen 1’s most recognizable Pokemon, Lapras’ design has made an impression on plenty of trainers over the years. The Water/Ice-type resembles a plesiosaur, with its spiky grey shell and flippers standing out as its most recognizable traits.

There’s not a lot to Lapras’ design, though its simplicity has a certain charm to it. Gigantamax Lapras adds much more to the initial design, putting more focus on its shell while maintaining the aesthetic of the original. Of course, many Pokemon fans will fulfill their dreams of riding a Lapras in Pokemon Sun & Moon , where they can use the Pokemon to surf across bodies of water.

25 Eevee

The Possibilities Are Endless For This Normal-Type

Type

Normal

Abilities

Run Away, Adaptability, Anticipation

Learned Moves

Swift, Double-Edge, Baby-Doll Eyes, Bite, Sand Attack

Forms

Gigantamax Eevee

Eevee is a Pokemon from the first generation of Pokemon games. It is a small, canine-like, Normal-type Pokemon that notably has many potential evolutions, each with a differing type. Among the fan-favorites of the so-called "Eeveelutions" include Umbreon, Sylveon, Jolteon, and Vaporeon.

The Pokemon that Eevee evolves into depends on some different factors, including the location Eevee is evolved in, or the item used to evolve it. It's been a fan topic for many years how Eeveelution designs would look for the rest of the types that have yet to be discovered, but hopefully, it won't be long for Nintendo to unveil them.

24 Mewtwo

Other Than Mew, It's Second To None

Type

Psychic, Psychic/Fighting (Mega Mewtwo X)

Abilities

Pressure, Unnerve, Steadfast (Mega Mewtwo X), Insomnia (Mega Mewtwo Y)

Learned Moves

Psystrike, Future Sight, Aura Sphere, Ancient Power, Life Dew, Mist, Recover

Forms

Mega Mewtwo X, Mega Mewtwo Y

The second-to-last Pokemon in the original Pokedex in Pokemon Red and Blue , Mewtwo is one of the most powerful Pokemon in existence. However, it can only be caught after beating the main story. Once the player becomes the Pokemon Champion, they can travel to Cerulean Cave to seek out Mewtwo, but it's best to save the Master Ball for this difficult fight.

What makes Mewtwo's design impressive is how disconnected it is from the rest of the Pokemon in the series. Mewtwo is more "unnatural" than other Pokemon, to convey its artificial creation, and its demeanor is more purposefully savage than any other Pokemon. It also helps that the Pokemon has one of the most iconic anime appearances in Mewtwo Strikes Back .

23 Umbreon

Eevee's Darkest Evolution Is Its Brightest

Type

Dark

Abilities

Synchronize, Inner Focus

Learned Moves

Snarl, Dark Pulse, Moonlight, Confuse Ray, Guard Swap, Sand Attack, Covet

Forms

N/A

The Eeveelutions don’t lack any creativity in their designs, with each one bringing some unique attributes to the table compared to other Pokemon of the same time. Gen 1 might have introduced the most at once, but Gen 2’s additions, the Dark-type Umbreon and Psychic-type Espeon bring a lot to the table once players evolve them at nighttime or in the daytime, respectively.

Umbreon gets a slight edge over Espeon thanks to its sleek appearance. Its design is simple compared to its alternatives, but it stands out in how it’s able to do more with less. New Eeveelutions are bound to be introduced in future generations. Whether they can match Umbreon’s design is up in the air, though Gen 6's Sylveon got pretty close.

22 Suicune

Any Form It Takes, Suicune Looks Cool

Type

Water, Water/Dragon (Walking Wake)

Abilities

Pressure, Inner Focus, Protosynthesis (Walking Wake)

Learned Moves

Surf, Water Pulse, Blizzard, Extrasensory, Crunch, Tailwind, Extreme Speed

Forms

Walking Wake

Suicune is a member of the Legendary beasts trio that first appeared in Pokemon Silver and Gold . The Legendary Pokemon Ho-oh resurrected Suicune after it had died in the fire that destroyed the Brass Tower. Suicune is a roaming Pokemon, which means the player may get their chance to catch it once they randomly encounter it in the wild.

Suicune's design is canine in origin and takes inspiration from wolves and other long-snouted breeds. However, Suicune only looks cooler with its Paradox form in Scarlet & Violet , Walking Wake, which is more dinosaur-inspired and boasts a secondary Dragon-typing.

21 Blaziken

This Fire Starter Packs A Punch

Type

Fire/Fighting

Abilities

Blaze, Speed Boost

Learned Moves

Blaze Kick, Flare Blitz, Reversal, Double Kick, Brave Bird, Sand Attack, Focus Energy

Forms

Mega Blaziken

The Gen 3 starters all had their own unique features that drew various trainers to them. But the one member of the trio that manages to consistently stand out is Blaziken, the Fire/Fighting-type evolution of Torchic, which boasts an incredible moveset and powerful Attack and Speed stats.

Blaziken’s design went through some rough patches before it developed into what fans are familiar with today. The original Torchic design had features that would be shelved until the Mega Blaziken design was introduced, and an early design for Latias featured arms and legs similar to Blaziken’s. Thankfully Blaziken's Mega Evolution only improves on its memorable design.

20 Milotic

Beauty Isn't Everything, But Milotic Is

Type

Water

Abilities

Marvel Scale, Competitive, Cute Charm

Learned Moves

Aqua Ring, Water Pulse, Disarming Voice, Coil, Dragon Tail, Attract

Forms

N/A

Milotic is a Water-type Pokemon that first appeared in Pokemon Ruby and Sapphire . This serpentine creature evolves from the humble Feebas when its Beauty condition, one of the game's numerous gameplay mechanics, is high enough. In later games, the player can evolve Feebas into Milotic by trading it while it holds a Prism Scale.

As even mentioned in the Pokemon's Pokedex entry, Milotic is one of the most elegant and beautiful Pokemon in existence. Its beauty is also responsible for inspiring the creation of many works of art, both in real life and in the lore of the Pokemon world. While its evolutionary line may take cues from Magikarp and Gyarados, Milotic is an improvement on all fronts.

19 Absol

Seeing This Pokemon Is Bad News, But Catching One Isn't

Type

Dark

Abilities

Pressure, Super Luck, Justified, Magic Bounce (Mega Absol)

Learned Moves

Night Slash, Sucker Punch, Future Sight, Detect, Swords Dance

Forms

Mega Absol

This Dark-type Pokemon debuted in Pokemon Ruby & Sapphire and has endeared itself to fans through its simplistic yet fascinating design. According to its original Pokedex entries, the Pokemon is known to appear as a warning when impending disasters are coming, which it is said to sense through the use of its curved, moon-shaped horn.

While there's enough to love about Absol's regular form, its Mega Evolution only makes the design even better. Mega Absol certainly gives off more vibes like an angel, with massive wings sprouting from its back. Even its appearance in the anime movie Jirachi: Wish Maker proves that it's not only well-designed, but well-intentioned in saving Ash and his friends.

18 Rayquaza

The Airborne Dragon Settles Legendary Feuds

Type

Dragon/Flying

Abilities

Air Lock, Delta Stream (Mega Rayquaza)

Learned Moves

Outrage, Twister, Dragon Ascent, Hurricane, Crunch, Rest, Ancient Power, Hyper Beam

Forms

Mega Rayquaza

Rayaquaza is one of the legendary Pokemon from the third generation, as well as the mascot of Pokemon Emerald . One of the most powerful Pokemon in the series, Rayquaza lives high in the atmosphere and typically only comes down to earth to prevent Groudon and Kyogre from fighting. Rayquaza can only be found and caught in Emerald when the player visits the Sky Pillar.

Taking inspiration from dragons depicted in many Asian mythologies, Rayquaza has a long serpentine body with two small forearms and three-fingered hands. The fins on its head and on multiple parts of its body help give it an aerodynamic design that conveys its dominance in the sky. Its Mega Evolution also boasts some of the most incredible stats in the entire franchise.

17 Lucario

Only The Strongest Trainers Master This 'Mon

Type

Fighting/Steel

Abilities

Steadfast, Inner Focus, Justified, Adaptability (Mega Lucario)

Learned Moves

Aura Sphere, Close Combat, Meteor Mash, Metal Sound, Dragon Pulse, Calm Mind, Bone Rush, Life Dew, Extreme Speed

Forms

Mega Lucario

Lucario is quite the special Pokemon, as it's capable of reading auras and communicating with humans through telepathy. It's a pretty strange trait for a Fighting/Steel-type Pokemon, as one would assume an aura-reading Pokemon would be Psychic-type. However, its Steel-type likely comes from the spikes in its chest and hands.

In the anime, Lucario is notable for its appearance in the movie Lucario and the Mystery of Mew , in which it's revealed that a Lucario has a strong bond with its trainer, Sir Aaron. However, most casual Pokemon fans recognize this Pokemon from its appearances in the Super Smash Bros series as a playable fighter, making for a pretty powerful foe in many games.

16 Garchomp

Cynthia Had The Right Idea With This Partner

Type

Dragon/Ground

Abilities

Sand Veil, Rough Skin, Sand Force (Mega Garchomp)

Learned Moves

Dragon Rush, Dragon Claw, Dig, Bulldoze, Sandstorm, Crunch, Take Down

Forms

Mega Garchomp

Many players had their first encounter with Garchomp in Pokemon Diamond & Pearl when they stood up against the Sinnoh Region Champion, Cynthia. Many players were taken aback by how difficult it was to take down the Ground and Dragon-type Pokemon, and it was even more frustrating prior to the introduction of Fairy-types in Generation 6.

Aside from its immense power, Garchomp features an amazing design, with massive "blade-shaped arms," spikes protruding from various parts of its body, and a unique head shape that is reminiscent of a hammerhead shark. Even its Mega Evolution only further enhances its shark-like qualities, though it doesn't get any change in typing.

15 Zoroark

Appearances Can Be Deceiving, But Zoroark Appears Cool

Type

Dark, Normal/Ghost (Hisuian form)

Abilities

Illusion

Learned Moves

Night Daze, Knock Off, Bitter Malice (Hisuian form), Shadow Sneak (Hisuian form), U-Turn, Agility, Fury Swipes

Forms

Hisuian Zoroark

Zoroark and its pre-evolution, Zorua, were the first Pokemon to be revealed from the Gen 5 games Pokemon Black & White , appearing in an anime movie leading up to the game's releases. It's a Dark-type Pokemon with the ability to create illusions, which it utilizes in battle by appearing like another Pokemon in a player's party, cleverly tricking naive opponents.

While Zoroark's design, with a long red ponytail and black tufts of fur, is cool enough, its regional form from Pokemon Legends: Arceus is only an improvement. In that game, Hisuian Zorua and Zoroark are both Normal/Ghost-types, with white and red fur that coils like spirits. It is said that Hisuian Zoroark is the embodiment of death, which is a lot more intense than its regular form.

14 Golurk

Its Massive Size Isn't The Only Impressive Thing About It

Type

Ground/Ghost

Abilities

Iron Fist, Klutz, No Guard

Learned Moves

Earthquake, Stomping Tantrum, Shadow Punch, Phantom Force, Hammer Arm, Heavy Slam, Mega Punch

Forms

N/A

Golurk is one of the most creative designs in the Pokemon franchise, debuting in the Gen 5 games Pokemon Black & White . The Ground/Ghost-type is based on ancient automatons, with its Pokedex entries claiming they were originally created as protectors of people and Pokemon. The crack in its chest contains unspeakable energy that will unleash if unsealed.

What's even more admirable about Golurk's design is the sheer scale. The anime depicts Golurk as the size of a building, which makes it pretty impressive if trainers manage to tame them. However, the in-game height is listed at just over 9 feet tall, so canonically Golurk is a little more manageably sized but still massive.

13 Greninja

Froakie's Evolution Gets Preferential Treatment

Type

Water/Dark

Abilities

Torrent, Protean, Battle Bond (Ash-Greninja)

Learned Moves

Water Shuriken, Hydro Pump, Night Slash, Lick, Extrasensory, Aerial Ace, Spikes, Haze, Substitute

Forms

Ash-Greninja

First introduced in Pokemon X and Y , Greninja is the final evolution in the Froakie evolution family. Froakie is one of the games' starter Pokemon, so getting a Greninja is as easy as picking Froakie at the start of the adventure. However, Greninja has been a popular Pokemon outside of Pokemon X&Y , appearing in the Super Smash Bros. series and in the anime.

Its striking design is heavily inspired by the classic depiction of Japanese ninjas that is often seen in popular media. However, its appearance in the anime upgraded its design by introducing Ash-Greninja, an alternate form that resembles Ash's outfit aesthetic thanks to the bond between Pokemon and trainer.

12 Hawlucha

A Fighting/Flying-Type Is A Trainer's Best Friend

Type

Fighting/Flying

Abilities

Limber, Unburden, Mold Breaker

Learned Moves

Flying Press, High Jump Kick, Bounce, Wing Attack, Hone Claws, Swords Dance

Forms

N/A

The Fighting/Flying-type Pokemon Hawlucha has a very unique design, resembling luchador wrestlers. Its introduction to the series was quite a comedy of errors, however, as the Pokemon was revealed in a gameplay leak that many presumed to be fake until the game's actual release. Thankfully it turned out true, as Hawlucha has many unique qualities for any Pokemon.

Aside from its notably colorful Shiny form, Hawlucha is also capable of learning the franchise's only dual-type move in Flying Press. While there are many expert fighters in the Pokedex, Hawlucha is the only one who brings a certain amount of style and showmanship to battles, as evidenced by Ash's Hawlucha in the anime series.

11 Noivern

Have You Heard How Cool This Dragon Is?

Type

Flying/Dragon

Abilities

Frisk, Infiltrator, Telepathy

Learned Moves

Hurricane, Air Cutter, Dragon Pulse, Moonlight, Absorb, Bite, Boomburst

Forms

N/A

As one of Ash’s Pokemon in the anime, Noivern has had plenty of screen time and won over tons of fans in the process. This Flying/Dragon-type’s design is certainly eye-grabbing, both in the anime and games, although it remains a mystery why Nintendo has yet to introduce the Sound-typing, as Noivern would be the perfect candidate.

As its name suggests, Noivern’s design seems to at least partially take inspiration from a wyvern, although its pre-evolution Noibat is more bat-like. What makes this Pokemon stand out are the speaker-like ears it sports, which are utilized with powerful moves like Boomburst.
